comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Rose Pitonof was from Dorchester MA, first female swimmer to swim from Manhattan to Coney Island, in August 1911, when she was 17 years old. The year before, she had completed the Boston Light swim. See South Boston: My Home Town: The History of an Ethnic Neighborhood by Thomas H. O'Connor (University Press of New England 1994). She was featured on a chewing tobacco card c.1913: www.bikiniscience.com/chronology/1910-1915_SS/PS1350_S/PS...

comment.author: 27583836@N08
comment._content: Via the Coney Island History Project's Facebook page On this day in history...Sept 18,1910... Rose Pitonof swam from the New York Yacht Club at the foot of East Twenty-third Street to Coney Island Lightship, a distance of 16-1/4 miles in a straight line, without any noticeable fatigue on her part. The 16 year old girl from Boston accomplished what male swimmers had tried... time and again without success. Rounding Norton's Point, she had a royal battle with the head tide. She made the distance in 5 hours and 8 minutes. Photo: Rose Pitonof, Champion Long-Distance Swimmer, Library of Congress, Bain collection www.facebook.com/pages/Coney-Island-History-Project/14934...

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content:
pennylrichardsca and Coney Island History Project:

Thank you for shedding more light on the amazing Rose Pitonof. We will expand the record when we update to include more details.
